description.narrative: As part of COVID19 preparedness and response Oxfam and Shaqodoon local partner in collaboration with ministry of health and Telesom company have jointly set up and launched an interactive COVID-19 call center in Hargeisa. The call center plays a vital role in the dissemination of up-to-date and accurate and reliable information to the public, it provides prerecorded prevention guidelines; audio-based symptoms pre-screening options; counseling and medical assistance from health professionals and referrals to the emergencyand quarantine centers nearby. The center also feeds the government a way of tracking suspect cases information for emergency action and is alternative mechanism for those have not physical access to government health facilities related to COVID. The call centerhas a toll free 24/7 available short code number (988) accessible from all over the country with 14 dedicated call agents who handle and process calls and voice messages, 2 professional doctors available for the management of suspect cases who provide counseling on daily bases to the callers and 2 technical assistance. The call center receives 294,427 calls since its inception. Shaqodoon sends daily reports of the center including information of the suspect cases to the ministry of health to inform their daily plans regarding COVID19. some of the Major project activities are : - Supporting your partners in adapting to Covid-19 situation so that they can continue to provide protection services - Adapting referrals to the newsituation # remotely? - Supporting Protection committees to adapt their activities/ prepare for activities during lockdown (e.g. material needed, technical advice) - Preparing to stay in touch with communities if movement restrictions get stricter (e.g.communication systems needed) - Remote protection monitoring

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.
